title: Can I say “Greetings” to everyone? - Quora

response.answer_text: You could if you chose to. There is no one technically stopping you from greeting people in this way. If you are asking whether you should, that depends on the impression that you want to give off. Many people find unexpected phrases as a turn-off, but others would find it refreshing. In a professional context, many people begin their emails with “Greetings,” yet will never say it in person. People tend to be more uncomfortable with verbal deviations from the normal than with written deviations. It would help if you had more context for the situation that you are in, because certain scenarios demand certain types of behavior and etiquette. In addition, are you combining this “Greetings” with a humorous alien-like voice? Context could make a big difference in how well-received this statement is.

Of course you can - if you are from Belucistan - and learned English in Kukurstan.! ( sorry, I am joking !). As for me,, I send my Greetings in written form - I don*t use this word when greeting someone viva - voce. Of course , saying * Greetings to everyone* is not actually a blatant mistake - but it is not so adequate like, say * Hi everyone! * Again, *Greetings to everyone* can be rather a written form (in a letter, book etc.) - while * Hi everyone* is the viva-voce (verbal) equivalent expression

I see no reason you shouldn’t. I am assuming you are in a situation where it is normal to say “Hello” or “How are you”, for example if you enter a store and encounter a clerk you know. However, if you say “Greetings” to every person you pass on the street, some will think it strange. If people I know say that to me, I would especially appreciate it since they chose to say something different.

You can, but not in Australia if you want people to like you. This form of greeting seems pretentious to us and just too overdone. Better to say hi, hello, good morning/afternoon, or g’day if it is to be casual or semi-casual. However, using “Greetings” as a salutation for cards or letters is not so much frowned upon.

Greetings! Yes, greetings is a lovely salutation. Hi, hello, wazzzzuppp, good morning, afternoon, evening and night. Bonjour. Fist bump. And many many more. I like saying, “greetings” sometimes when it isn’t quite a certain time for morning/night address. It’s friendly. Structured. And polite. :)

“Greetings “ is not wrong, but let us be a little polite and personal to have said... Hello! or Good day! The people who can hear will somehow return the greetings as they feel it to be directed to them. “ Greetings" can be use more in written communication bur not in addressing a group of people or crowd.
